displayed_text: Patient: Right, that’s what I was thinking originally, Family Member: And see what happens with medication. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um, now about the uh hormone shots. So he’s covered for three months. After that expires he should get another shot and you start chemo? Doctor: He will have another shot, so it should be in here already. I will put it in. Family Member: In January. Doctor: So if you’ve already got an appointment for January – Family Member: January thirty. Doctor: Yeah, that will be your next shot. So typically I schedule that no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re always going to come in and see me or (says name) Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Once a day; I’m taking it once a day now. Doctor: Once a day. Patient: Yeah, I’m taking it at night, so you know to get ahead of the pain. But it’s been pretty good. I haven’t been in much hip pain lately, hardly at all. Doctor: The Simvastatin twenty milligrams a day. That’s your Zocor. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: Your Flomax or Tamsulosin once a day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Venlafaxine or Effexor for mood – thirty-seven and a half. Patient: I don’t know. I don’t know. What’s another name for it? Doctor: Venlafaxine or Effexor. Patient: Oh yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, I do, yeah. Doctor: And the Enzalutamide, you’re still taking four pills a day? Patient: Xtandi?

Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that? Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh some data that said people who are on Enzalutamide stay on Enzalutamide and get these drugs uh may have a higher response rate, and that’s what we are testing. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have done this already in fifteen men and I think three people benefited for a period of time, relatively short. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But still benefited and so they did not have Enzalutamide or the Xtandi, so we’re doing fifteen more who have Xtandi uh and seeing whether or not it’s a higher response because of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So technically your ARV7 right now is positive enough to go on, your PSA is rising, you’re on the Xtandi, okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The worry is the lungs, okay because this is a treatment that if we turn on your immune system so loud it can attack your normal body. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So you can get a non-infectious pneumonia and get really short of breath and it fills up with scar tissue and s tuff like that and that we have to stop with steroids.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. I will. Doctor: You could do it the same day, but then we don’t – Patient: No, I will. Doctor: But I just have to tell you about aliens, and I’ve got nothing else to talk to you about. Patient: Well, yeah, I know. I’ll get my daughter over here. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay. Patient: The nurse, his nurse is mailing me the paper forms, but I will, I’m just going to tell M_ when I walk up in here. Because then it shows right up in my record; you guys have it in a day or two. Doctor: Yep. Patient: I don’t have to deal with one extra fax. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And all that. Doctor: So, April seventeenth for me and then come in any time before that for PSA.

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Before we started on the Xtandi and everything, you know the study. But since then we really barely even see those lymph nodes and even so they’ve been so small. Family Member: Great. Patient: So does that indicate that what your husband did worked? Family Member: Well no, that’s the bone scan. Doctor: No it doesn’t. Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean this is. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I have to say, though, that you look better today post radiation than before we started. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were really uncomfortable. You know? Patient: Yeah. And now I did have some. Doctor: And you’re you know better. Patient: Uh, my back is a lot better. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Now I did have a little diarrhea. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It didn’t start until after I got home.

Healthcare Professional: Just let me know when you’re done and I’ll come turn it off. Doctor: Okay, great. Thank you. Okay. Patient: Alrighty. Doctor: Okay. All right. So first we have to go over results. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have the CAT scan- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -that showed probably no evidence of metastatic disease, okay, meaning no evidence of cancer that we can see. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The reason why I say probably- did you get these results on MyChart? Patient: Nuh-uh. Doctor: Okay, are you are you on MyChart? Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there.

Patient: Run down. Yeah, it did, it was making me really tired. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean, I was surviving--I was able to get by with work and stuff, it was-- Family Member: You got really--you were really, really tired. Doctor: I may just adjust you today because if we can keep that eye and, you know, everything else from getting worse-- Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful. Doctor: --because the nerves affecting things is a big problem. If that happens, then that's tougher to reverse. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So let's go one notch slightly lower in terms of your dose. Patient: Okay. Yeah, I missed it yesterday, I was going to come in all dressed up as a doctor, and-- Doctor: Yep. Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: and that almost yielded nothing either. You had like one abnormality at zero point one percent as in I don’t think you have much floating around which is kind of good but nothing that we can sort of target. Patient: Yeah, Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, we got a target something? Doctor: Well, I think we… Patient: Got to find out if we… Doctor: Exactly. Patient: We got to find out. Doctor: So, you guys now are on the same page as me in terms of what to expect after the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I never order stuff when it’s, I don’t want it to be a mystery. You guys should know exactly what we’re going to do depending on the results. Patient: Okay. I like that.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And on a clinical trial, we don’t know if more is better, but that third drug, if you were to get it, starts to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: If you don’t get it- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - you still have two things that we know kill cancer cells that make people live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Now, is he going to have a body scan at one point to see what’s happening with the cancer cells? Uh she should have that body scan uh that Dr. ____ said that it’s . Now is it down the road? Is it something that you plan to do or does it matter? Or how would you know that the cancer is shrinking? Patient: That the cancer is shrinking.

Patient: No. Doctor: Um hum. Have you been losing or gaining any weight? Patient: Uh, I guess I been Doctor: And do you think that’s because your appetite has dropped or you’re losing even if you’re eating the same amount. Patient: Somewhat the same amount. Doctor: Okay. And can you remind me who lives with you at home? Are you on your own or do you have other family members with you? Patient: Um my sister and my great-niece. Doctor: Sister and great-niece. A-and i-i-is your great-niece working or is she at home? Is she- Patient: She-she work. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhm. She probably gon’ be there Doctor: Okay. Well um, you might be right that the PSA level could be rising. We’ll find out by uh later this afternoon or tomorrow morning at the latest.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ours isn’t back yet, but his is going up. Patient: Yeah I mean I… Doctor: Mhmm Patient: I think I started chemo and I was in the low thirties. I went down in to twenties and I’m back up to thirty I think the last one from B______. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. You know the lymph nodes are starting to grow again. Just plumpier um Patient: I had a CT scan Doctor: Yeah Patient: this morning and we asked for a stat read, but it… Doctor: Yeah. That’s the one. Patient: Okay. Wow. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m reading Patient: That’s- They were really quick. Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Other: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Other

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think like taking a globe and a string or something and see. Patient: Yeah. I didn’t understand why- Doctor: I don’t quite understand how it’s shorter, but it’s shorter. Family Member: But we could see on the plane, you know, on the screen the pattern he’s flying in- Doctor: Yeah. You go up. Right. You go up along Canada. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. Because usually when the times I’ve flown, it’s either dark or cloudy, but this is one like, holy crap, and my phone even said, welcome. Doctor: You know when you fly sometimes, your cell phone will pick up. I must not have had it turned off. It said, like welcome to Greenland. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, you know, numb hands and feet, but in general the trial allows you to do that and then if you’re not on the vitamin C everybody starts to get the vitamin C. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You kind of pretty much know if you are on the vitamin C though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you do get flushing and you know kind of like what you think about high-dose vitamins. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so I think it’s worth a go at least to think about it.
